t: Job 40
Moreover*p the Lord*s answered Job, and said,
Shall*p he that contendeth with the Almighty instruct him? he that reproveth God, let him answer it.
Then*p Job answered the Lord,*s and said,
Behold,*p I am vile; what shall I answer thee? I will lay mine hand upon my mouth.
Once*p have I spoken; but I will not answer: yea, twice; but I will proceed no further.
Then*p answered the Lord*s unto Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
Gird*p up thy loins now like a man: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
Wilt*p thou also disannul my judgment? wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be righteous?
Hast*p thou an arm like God? or canst thou thunder with a voice like him?
Deck*p thyself now with majesty and excellency; and array thyself with glory and beauty.
Cast*p abroad the rage of thy wrath: and behold every one that is proud, and abase him.
Look*p on every one that is proud, and bring him low; and tread down the wicked in their place.
Hide*p them in the dust together; and bind their faces in secret.
Then*p will I also confess unto thee that thine own right hand can save thee.
Behold*p now behemoth, which I made with thee; he eateth grass as an ox.
Lo*p now, his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the navel of his belly.
He*p moveth his tail like a cedar: the sinews of his stones are wrapped together.
His*p bones are as strong pieces of brass; his bones are like bars of iron.
He*p is the chief of the ways of God: he that made him can make his sword to approach unto him.
Surely*p the mountains bring him forth food, where all the beasts of the field play.
He*p lieth under the shady trees, in the covert of the reed, and fens.
The*p shady trees cover him with their shadow; the willows of the brook compass him about.
Behold,*p he drinketh up a river, and hasteth not: he trusteth that he can draw up Jordan into his mouth.
He*p taketh it with his eyes: his nose pierceth through snares.
